title: 112_hr6427
content: The Act titled "Capitalizing Workforce Development Act of 2012" establishes a Job Training Resources Grant Program. The Capitalizing Workforce Development Act of 2012 establishes a Job Training Resources Grant Program under Section 403(a) of the Social Security Act. This program provides grants for the purchase, renovation, construction, or lease of real property to support qualified self-sustaining job programs that offer job training and placement services to individuals with employment challenges. The Job Training Resources Grant Program provides grants for job training services to individuals with employment challenges. Priority is given to applicants with successful experience in establishing self-sustaining job programs. Applicants can participate in other federal programs. Eligible applicants must demonstrate successful experience in establishing self-sustaining job programs or have local organizations awarded a grant under section 413(h)(3)(A). Eligible applicants include national organizations, States or political subdivisions, and Indian tribes or tribal organizations. The grant conditions and requirements for eligible applicants include establishing job placement performance goals for self-sustaining job programs operated by the grantee. The grant conditions require establishing job placement goals for self-sustaining job programs operated by the grantee, with performance assessment dates set by the Secretary. The Secretary must also protect the federal interest in real property purchased or improved with grant funds. The Secretary must protect the federal interest in real property purchased or improved with grant funds, and eligible applicants must distribute funds among local organizations for self-sustaining job programs. $200,000,000 is appropriated for grants in fiscal year 2013. $200,000,000 is appropriated for grants under this paragraph for fiscal year 2013, with a recapture penalty for failure to meet job placement goals in self-sustaining job programs. Repayment to the Treasury is required for any such failure. The Secretary shall require repayment of funds in proportion to the degree of failure to meet job placement goals. Repayment shall be made over a 10-year period with no interest accruing. Alternatively, the recipient may comply with the goals to avoid repayment, as prescribed by the Secretary. In case of state failure, specific actions will be taken. The Secretary may require repayment of funds for failure to meet job placement goals, with repayment over a 10-year period. States facing penalties may have their grants reduced instead. State penalty limitations do not apply in this case. Additionally, there is an exclusion from the state reasonable cause exception under the Social Security Act. The exclusion from state penalty limitations under the Social Security Act is amended to include subsection (17). The text chunk is about an offset to ensure compliance with Paygo regulations.
